block.p: Mideast Summit Produces Promises to Halt Violence Israelis and Palestinians agreed to take immediate steps to try to stem the violence raging in the West Bank and Gaza. Israel agreed to reopen the Gaza airport, end the border closings and withdraw some forces. The Palestinians said they would crack down on incitement against Israel and rearrest Islamic fundamentalists whom Palestinian officials released from prison last week.
Israeli soldiers continued to battle Palestinians throughout the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
Arab leaders prepared for a meeting of Arab League heads of state -- the first such high-level conference in 10 years -- that will test regional support for a negotiated peace.

Investigation of Warship Blast Yemeni security officials have searched an Aden apartment that they suspect was used for several days by men who may have played a role in the deadly attack on the destroyer Cole last week.

Congress Moves on Debt Relief Congressional leaders agreed to allot $435 million for the United States share of a global debt relief initiative this year. The agreement awaits final approval by both houses.

Security Summit in Brazil Defense ministers from throughout the Western Hemisphere began four days of meetings in Brazil aimed at strengthening military and security cooperation in the region. But the formal agenda was overshadowed by the deepening conflict in Colombia and the increased American commitment there.

Serb Calls on Montenegro The new president of Yugoslavia, Vojislav Kostunica, made his first official visit to Montenegro, turning his attention to forging a new relationship with the independent-minded republic, the last Yugoslav republic still joined with Serbia.

Train Crash in Britain Kills 4 At least 4 people were killed and 33 were injured when a high-speed train heading north from London derailed, renewing concern about the safety of Britain's privatized railroads.
Voters Ask the Questions In Last of Three Debates Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush met in St. Louis for their third and final planned debate, a 90-minute town-meeting format.

Crash Alters Political Scene Democrats and political analysts said the death of Gov. Mel Carnahan of Missouri in a plane crash had thrown the politics of his important swing state into disarray and had probably diminished the Democrats' chances of retaking the Senate.
The pilot, the governor's son Roger reported problems with the twin-engine plane's instruments shortly before the crash, in rainy weather.

Veto Threat Over Medicare The White House said President Clinton would veto the latest version of a bill restoring money to Medicare because it gave too much money to H.M.O.'s. The Clinton administration insisted that Congress shift money from H.M.O.'s to hospitals, home health care agencies and other health care providers.

Scientist Discusses Secrets Wen Ho Lee, the former government scientist who pleaded guilty to mishandling nuclear secrets, met with federal officials in Albuquerque and began explaining his actions, as required by his plea agreement.

Los Angeles Transit Strike Ends Negotiators reached a tentative agreement to resolve the monthlong walkout that shut down the nation's second-largest bus system and has stranded hundreds of thousands of commuters. Buses were expected to resume running this morning. A ratification vote is set for tonight.

Keeping Calorie-Conscious Many obesity experts are coming to believe that the only way for most people to control their weight is to be highly aware of food, planning their eating and planning exercise to burn off calories and never letting a day go by when what to eat and how much to eat and how much to exercise are not on their minds.

Hillary Clinton's Vision Of U.S. Foreign Policy Hillary Rodham Clinton called for the United States to reject isolationism and aggressively engage itself in world affairs in the tradition of President Harry S. Truman. She said the definition of American interests should be expanded beyond the protection of American life and property to include women's and human rights, environmental protection and the control of deadly disease. Her opponent, Rick A. Lazio, said her standard for intervention was too lax.

$53 Million and Counting A New York Times poll found that most New Jersey voters do not care that Jon S. Corzine, a wealthy Democrat, is shattering spending records in his Senate race, which he leads by 12 percentage points.
Mayor's Wife in 'Monologues' Donna Hanover, the estranged wife of Mayor Giuliani, delivered monologues on orgasm, lesbian sex and the rape of Bosnian women in her debut in ''The Vagina Monologues.''

Less Praise May Be Better Many educators and child psychologists are coming to the conclusions that less praise is often better and that frequent praise for unexceptional actions can actually have a negative effect on children.
The Yankees Get on Board The Yanks set up the first Subway Series since 1956 by beating Seattle, 9-7, to clinch the A.L. pennant. The World Series begins on Saturday.
Reversal of Fortunes The recent decline of many Internet companies' stocks has darkened the mood at Agenda, a major computer industry conference.

Mixed News From Intel Intel, which warned investors last month that earnings would not meet expectations, reported third-quarter numbers that beat analysts' lowered forecasts. But the chip maker also reported stagnant sales and projected a lackluster holiday season.

Cutting Heat-Trapping Cases DuPont, Shell, Alcan Aluminium and four other large companies joined a growing list of businesses promising substantial voluntary reductions in the release of greenhouse gases.

Tire Maker Layoffs Bridgestone/Firestone, acknowledging a falloff in sales after reports of deaths linked to the failure of Firestone tires, said it would indefinitely lay off 450 workers at its factory in Decatur, Ill., and then close it and two others for two to four weeks.
Editorials: The final presidential debate; Mideast crisis management; after 44 years, another Subway Series. Columns: Paul Krugman.
